body_content.explanation: used to describe something that is organized in two levels or stages:
examples: Council functions throughout Cornwall were organised on a two-tier basis, with a county council and district councils.
The company proposed to replace its two-tier board with a single board of directors.
The disaster led to the introduction of a two-tiered security system at American airports.

body_content.explanation: used to describe a system that is not the same for all groups of people, and gives more advantages to one group than to another group:
examples: We have a two-tier system in this city, because there are so many private schools.
Broadband prices are now two-tier, with providers charging as much as £100 extra if you live in the country.

body_content.explanation: used to describe something that has two levels, one on top of the other:
examples: The covered market is an attractive old two-tier building.
